keyTakeAways: John Bolton, a former national security adviser to President Donald Trump, has been indicted by a federal grand jury in Maryland.
The indictment includes 18 counts: eight for transmitting national defense information and ten for retaining such information.
This case involves significant implications for the handling of classified national security information and the legal accountability of former high-level government officials.
The indictment is part of ongoing legal scrutiny into the use and disclosure of sensitive national security information during and after the Trump administration.

summaryOfNewsArticle: John Bolton, former national security adviser to President Donald Trump, has been indicted by a federal grand jury in Maryland on 18 counts, including eight for transmitting and ten for retaining national defense information. This development raises significant concerns about the handling of classified information during and after the Trump administration and underscores ongoing legal scrutiny of former high-level officials. The case is relevant to both domestic legal processes and international perceptions of U.S. national security governance.
